A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. I Early Friday morning the teams with trunks and baskets I began to arrive and by ton oclock about the time of the parade at least 1500 people were I thronging the streets. The town was turned over to the farm ers and they enjoyed the day in every way.  . The Farm ville Silver Band furnished splendid music for the occasion and our boys girls joined in the parade and the festivities of the occasion. President of the County Union, J. W . Cawthorn, Jr., introduced A. B. Thornhill, who spoke on the objects of the Union and welcomed the far mers, their wives and daugh ters and the visitors to the ele g an t dinner w hich was spread on the Court Green, Mr. F. A. He paid Appomattox a high com plim ent on her splen did enterprise, progress and commended especially the I great Work being done by Prof. Crawley in our fine Agricul tural College. He told the farm ers how to beautify their  homes and keep the boys on the farm. Mr. LaBaume is a good speaker and the large audience enjoyed his rem arks very much and no doubt w ill gather some inspiration there from fpr greater effort tow ards real progress. . President Ganaway, pf Cum berland, w ae present and made an address w hich was much enjoyed.  Btate Secretary D. M. Blank- inship, of Campbell County, was also present and m ade a good business talk to the far mers. The day was strictly a far m ers day and they are to be congratulated on the big suc cess of their picnic, and now we w ant to move that they m ake thefourth Friday in Au gust every year the annual picnic day of the Farm ers Union at Appomattox. The interest and attendance shows th at the Union is here to stay and th at the substantial saving which is being made to the farm ers in their respective Unions is worth the considera tion of those who are not mem bers. There were several m atch games of base ball played, and the entire day was given over to one of pleasure and social intercourse. Come again farm ers, and long live the Union.
